title: VERBS
subtitle: resembles, differs from, takes after
explanation: Use comparative verbs to show how things are similar or different. These verbs are more formal and precise than using 'be similar/different'.

sets.setTitle: Set 1: Similarity (resembles, takes after, has in common)

examples.before: The new model <<is similar to>> the previous one.
examples.after: The new model **<<resembles>>** the previous one.

examples.before: Sarah <<is similar to>> her mother in appearance.
examples.after: Sarah **<<takes after>>** her mother in appearance.

examples.before: Both languages <<share>> many features.
examples.after: Both languages **<<have much in common>>**.

examples.before: This painting <<looks like>> a Monet.
examples.after: This painting **<<resembles>>** a Monet.

examples.before: He <<is like>> his father in personality.
examples.after: He **<<takes after>>** his father in personality.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Difference (differs from, contrasts with, distinguishes from)

examples.before: This approach <<is different from>> the traditional method.
examples.after: This approach **<<differs from>>** the traditional method.

examples.before: His opinion <<is opposite to>> mine.
examples.after: His opinion **<<contrasts with>>** mine.

examples.before: Quality <<makes this product different from>> the others.
examples.after: Quality **<<distinguishes this product from>>** the others.

examples.before: These results <<are not the same as>> our expectations.
examples.after: These results **<<differ from>>** our expectations.

examples.before: Her style <<is very different from>> contemporary fashion.
examples.after: Her style **<<contrasts with>>** contemporary fashion.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Comparison (compares to/with, varies from, corresponds to)

examples.before: This system <<is similar to>> the one used in Japan.
examples.after: This system **<<compares to>>** the one used in Japan.

examples.before: Prices <<are different>> depending on the season.
examples.after: Prices **<<vary>>** depending on the season.

examples.before: The results <<match>> our predictions exactly.
examples.after: The results **<<correspond to>>** our predictions exactly.

examples.before: Her account <<is different from>> the witness statement.
examples.after: Her account **<<varies from>>** the witness statement.

examples.before: We can <<make a comparison between>> the two systems.
examples.after: We can **<<compare>>** the two systems.

title: ADJECTIVES
subtitle: similar to, different from, identical to
explanation: Use comparative adjectives to describe relationships between things. These phrases are followed by 'to' or 'from' depending on whether they show similarity or difference.

sets.setTitle: Set 1: Similarity (similar to, identical to, comparable to)

examples.before: This design <<resembles>> the original version.
examples.after: This design is **<<similar to>>** the original version.

examples.before: The two documents <<are exactly the same>>.
examples.after: The two documents are **<<identical to>>** each other.

examples.before: This price <<can be compared to>> last year's rates.
examples.after: This price is **<<comparable to>>** last year's rates.

examples.before: Both systems <<work in the same way>>.
examples.after: Both systems are **<<similar to>>** one another.

examples.before: These results <<match>> the previous study exactly.
examples.after: These results are **<<identical to>>** the previous study.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Difference (different from, distinct from, dissimilar to)

examples.before: This method <<doesn't resemble>> traditional approaches.
examples.after: This method is **<<different from>>** traditional approaches.

examples.before: Her accent <<clearly differs from>> a British one.
examples.after: Her accent is **<<distinct from>>** a British one.

examples.before: The new policy <<doesn't match>> the old one at all.
examples.after: The new policy is **<<dissimilar to>>** the old one.

examples.before: These findings <<contrast with>> earlier research.
examples.after: These findings are **<<different from>>** earlier research.

examples.before: His approach <<stands apart from>> conventional methods.
examples.after: His approach is **<<distinct from>>** conventional methods.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Equivalence & Sameness (the same as, equivalent to, alike)

examples.before: The digital version <<equals>> the printed edition.
examples.after: The digital version is **<<the same as>>** the printed edition.

examples.before: One euro <<equals roughly>> one dollar at the moment.
examples.after: One euro is **<<equivalent to>>** one dollar at the moment.

examples.before: Both sisters <<look very similar>>.
examples.after: Both sisters are **<<alike>>** in appearance.

examples.before: Your answer <<matches>> mine exactly.
examples.after: Your answer is **<<the same as>>** mine.

examples.before: This qualification <<equals>> a university degree.
examples.after: This qualification is **<<equivalent to>>** a university degree.

title: CORRELATIVE
subtitle: the more... the better
explanation: Use 'the...the' to show that two things change together. Use 'both...and', 'neither...nor', 'either...or' to connect two equal elements. These create balanced, sophisticated comparisons.
structure: the + comparative, the + comparative OR both/neither/either...and/nor/or

examples.before: When you practice <<more>>, you get <<better>>.
examples.after: **<<The more>>** you practice, **<<the better>>** you get.

examples.before: As prices become <<higher>>, demand gets <<lower>>.
examples.after: **<<The higher>>** the prices, **<<the lower>>** the demand.

examples.before: When she studies <<harder>>, her grades become <<better>>.
examples.after: **<<The harder>>** she studies, **<<the better>>** her grades become.

examples.before: If you leave <<earlier>>, you'll arrive <<sooner>>.
examples.after: **<<The earlier>>** you leave, **<<the sooner>>** you'll arrive.

examples.before: As you learn <<more>>, you realize you know <<less>>.
examples.after: **<<The more>>** you learn, **<<the less>>** you realize you know.

examples.before: The course is interesting. It's also challenging.
examples.after: The course is **<<both>>** interesting **<<and>>** challenging.

examples.before: She speaks French. She also speaks German.
examples.after: She speaks **<<both>>** French **<<and>>** German.

examples.before: He's qualified. He's also experienced.
examples.after: He's **<<both>>** qualified **<<and>>** experienced.

examples.before: The film was entertaining. It was thought-provoking too.
examples.after: The film was **<<both>>** entertaining **<<and>>** thought-provoking.

examples.before: They visited Paris. They also went to Rome.
examples.after: They visited **<<both>>** Paris **<<and>>** Rome.

examples.before: I don't like coffee. I don't like tea <<either>>.
examples.after: I like **<<neither>>** coffee **<<nor>>** tea.

examples.before: You can have the red one. Or you can choose the blue one.
examples.after: You can have **<<either>>** the red one **<<or>>** the blue one.

examples.before: He didn't call. He didn't send a message <<either>>.
examples.after: He **<<neither>>** called **<<nor>>** sent a message.

examples.before: We can meet on Tuesday. Wednesday would work too.
examples.after: We can meet **<<either>>** on Tuesday **<<or>>** Wednesday.

examples.before: She wasn't interested. She wasn't surprised <<either>>.
examples.after: She was **<<neither>>** interested **<<nor>>** surprised.

title: LINKING WORDS
subtitle: by contrast, on the other hand
explanation: Use linking words to show contrast or opposition between ideas. These make your writing more sophisticated and help organize complex comparisons clearly.

examples.before: Traditional methods are slow. <<But>> modern techniques are efficient.
examples.after: Traditional methods are slow, **<<whereas>>** modern techniques are efficient.

examples.before: She prefers classical music. <<But>> her brother loves rock.
examples.after: She prefers classical music, **<<while>>** her brother loves rock.

examples.before: Some people enjoy city life. <<But>> others prefer the countryside.
examples.after: Some people enjoy city life, **<<whereas>>** others prefer the countryside.

examples.before: The north is mountainous. <<But>> the south is flat.
examples.after: The north is mountainous, **<<while>>** the south is flat.

examples.before: He's very outgoing. <<But>> his sister is quite shy.
examples.after: He's very outgoing, **<<whereas>>** his sister is quite shy.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Contrast between sentences (however, nevertheless, nonetheless)

examples.before: The project was expensive. <<But>> it was worth the investment.
examples.after: The project was expensive. **<<However>>**, it was worth the investment.

examples.before: The task seemed impossible. <<But>> the team completed it successfully.
examples.after: The task seemed impossible. **<<Nevertheless>>**, the team completed it successfully.

examples.before: Critics praised the film. <<But>> it didn't perform well commercially.
examples.after: Critics praised the film. **<<Nonetheless>>**, it didn't perform well commercially.

examples.before: The weather was terrible. <<But>> we enjoyed our holiday.
examples.after: The weather was terrible. **<<However>>**, we enjoyed our holiday.

examples.before: She lacked experience. <<But>> she got the job anyway.
examples.after: She lacked experience. **<<Nevertheless>>**, she got the job anyway.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Direct opposition (by/in contrast, on the other hand, conversely)

examples.before: Public transport is cheap. Private cars, <<on the opposite side>>, are expensive.
examples.after: Public transport is cheap. Private cars, **<<by contrast>>**, are expensive.

examples.before: Some argue for more regulation. <<Others say the opposite>> and want less government control.
examples.after: Some argue for more regulation. **<<On the other hand>>**, others want less government control.

examples.before: Prices rose in the city. <<Doing the opposite>>, they fell in rural areas.
examples.after: Prices rose in the city. **<<Conversely>>**, they fell in rural areas.

examples.before: The report suggested expansion. The data, <<showing the opposite>>, indicated contraction.
examples.after: The report suggested expansion. The data, **<<in contrast>>**, indicated contraction.

examples.before: Theory emphasizes planning. Practice, <<differently>>, requires flexibility.
examples.after: Theory emphasizes planning. Practice, **<<on the other hand>>**, requires flexibility.

title: STANDARD FORMS
subtitle: as...as, more/-er, most/-est
explanation: Use standard forms to compare two things (comparative) or show one is the best/worst in a group (superlative). Short adjectives use -er/-est, while longer ones use more/most.

examples.before: This phone costs <<the same as>> that one.
examples.after: This phone is **<<as expensive as>>** that one.

examples.before: She doesn't run <<at the same speed as>> her sister.
examples.after: She doesn't run **<<as fast as>>** her sister.

examples.before: The sequel was <<equally good>> compared to the original.
examples.after: The sequel was **<<as good as>>** the original.

examples.before: Today's weather isn't <<at the same warmth as>> yesterday.
examples.after: Today isn't **<<as warm as>>** yesterday.

examples.before: This exam was <<equal in difficulty to>> the last one.
examples.after: This exam was **<<as difficult as>>** the last one.

examples.before: A laptop has <<greater convenience>> compared to a desktop.
examples.after: A laptop is **<<more convenient than>>** a desktop.

examples.before: This solution shows <<greater simplicity>> than the previous one.
examples.after: This solution is **<<simpler than>>** the previous one.

examples.before: Digital books cost <<a smaller amount>> compared to printed ones.
examples.after: Digital books are **<<less expensive than>>** printed ones.

examples.before: His second novel achieved <<greater success>> than his first.
examples.after: His second novel was **<<more successful than>>** his first.

examples.before: Summer days have <<greater length>> compared to winter days.
examples.after: Summer days are **<<longer than>>** winter days.

examples.before: No mountain in Europe has <<greater height>> than Mont Blanc.
examples.after: Mont Blanc is **<<the highest>>** mountain in Europe.

examples.before: No city in the world is <<more expensive>> than Tokyo.
examples.after: Tokyo is **<<the most expensive>>** city in the world.

examples.before: This method is <<more effective>> than any other approach.
examples.after: This is **<<the most effective>>** method.

examples.before: No problem was <<as difficult>> as the final question.
examples.after: The final question was **<<the most difficult>>** problem.

examples.before: Winter is <<colder>> than any other season here.
examples.after: Winter is **<<the coldest>>** season here.

title: SUPERLATIVE + PERFECT
subtitle: the best I have ever seen
explanation: Combine superlatives with present perfect to describe the most extreme experience in your life so far. This structure is very common in spoken and written English.
structure: the most/-est + (noun) + subject + have/has ever + past participle

examples.before: I've <<never seen>> a <<better>> film than this one.
examples.after: This is **<<the best film I have ever seen>>**.

examples.before: She's <<never read>> a <<worse>> book than that one.
examples.after: That's **<<the worst book she has ever read>>**.

examples.before: We've <<never had>> a <<better>> holiday than last summer.
examples.after: Last summer was **<<the best holiday we have ever had>>**.

examples.before: I've <<never eaten>> <<worse>> food than at that restaurant.
examples.after: That was **<<the worst food I have ever eaten>>**.

examples.before: He's <<never given>> a <<better>> presentation than today's.
examples.after: Today was **<<the best presentation he has ever given>>**.

examples.before: I've <<never visited>> a <<more beautiful>> place than this.
examples.after: This is **<<the most beautiful place I have ever visited>>**.

examples.before: She's <<never met>> a <<more interesting>> person than him.
examples.after: He's **<<the most interesting person she has ever met>>**.

examples.before: We've <<never faced>> a <<more challenging>> project than this one.
examples.after: This is **<<the most challenging project we have ever faced>>**.

examples.before: They've <<never seen>> a <<more impressive>> performance.
examples.after: It was **<<the most impressive performance they have ever seen>>**.

examples.before: I've <<never encountered>> a <<less helpful>> service than theirs.
examples.after: That was **<<the least helpful service I have ever encountered>>**.

examples.before: This is <<among the best>> books I've read.
examples.after: This is **<<one of the best books I have ever read>>**.

examples.before: He's <<among the most talented>> musicians I've heard.
examples.after: He's **<<one of the most talented musicians I have ever heard>>**.

examples.before: That was <<among the most difficult>> decisions I've made.
examples.after: That was **<<one of the most difficult decisions I have ever made>>**.

examples.before: She's <<among the kindest>> people I've met.
examples.after: She's **<<one of the kindest people I have ever met>>**.

examples.before: This is <<among the worst>> experiences I've had.
examples.after: This is **<<one of the worst experiences I have ever had>>**.
